channel.title: Yahoo! News: Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright (c) 2004 Yahoo! Inc. All rights reserved.

item.title: Ridge Resigns As Homeland Security Chief (AP)
item.description: AP - Tom Ridge's successor as chief of the Homeland Security Department will have to unify a sprawling bureaucracy, a deadly serious job where failure could put the United States at risk of another terror attack.

item.title: Bush to Thank Canadians for Post-9/11 Aid (AP)
item.description: AP - When the United States closed its airspace after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, more than 200 airliners were diverted to airports across Canada, where stranded travelers were welcomed into homes.

item.title: Ukraine Parliament Votes Out Government (AP)
item.description: AP - Ukraine's parliament brought down the government Wednesday, approving a no-confidence motion as international mediators gathered in the capital to try to bring the spiraling political crisis to a peaceful resolution.

item.title: U.N. Election Chief: Iraqi Vote on Track (AP)
item.description: AP - Preparations for the Jan. 30 national election are on track despite continuing violence and calls for delaying or boycotting the vote, the U.N. election chief in Iraq says.

item.title: 6 Americans Confirmed Dead in Afghan Crash (AP)
item.description: AP - Search teams have recovered the bodies of six Americans who died when their plane crashed high in Afghanistan's snow-covered mountains, U.S. military officials said Wednesday.

item.title: China Paying Price for Industrial Boom (AP)
item.description: AP - A pair of accidents that killed more than 300 miners has underscored the human price China pays for its booming economy and ravenous appetite for coal, an industry that's seen more than 4,500 workers killed on the job this year.

item.title: Surgery Performed Aboard 'Air Hospital' (AP)
item.description: AP - Doctors on a turbulence-free flight performed surgery 19,000 feet above the jungles of Colombia on the inaugural outing of the military's "Air Hospital," the country's new effort to save the lives of troops wounded in its war against Marxist insurgents.

item.title: 'Jeopardy!' Whiz Ends 74-Game Win Streak (AP)
item.description: AP - Following his remarkable run as the "Jeopardy!" whiz, Ken Jennings is famous enough to be trailed by a fan in the subway, is penning a book and, of course, has $2,520,700 in winnings to decide how to spend.

item.title: Holiday Shopping Gets Off to Modest Start (AP)
item.description: AP - The first holiday shopping weekend of the year may have started with a bang, but it ended with a whimper, evidence from two groups that track sales showed on Tuesday.

item.title: Fans Chant 'Fire Gundy' in Rockets Loss (AP)
item.description: AP - The Houston Rockets were finishing up one of their worst performances of the season when a chant rang out from behind the bench.

item.title: Homeland Security Chief Ridge Resigns (Reuters)
item.description: Reuters - U.S. Homeland Security Secretary Tom Ridge, who headed President Bush's efforts to build up domestic security after the Sept. 11 attacks, resigned on Tuesday.

item.title: Bush to Hail Canadians for Response to Sept. 11 (Reuters)
item.description: Reuters - President Bush, scorned by many in Canada for the Iraq war, will hark back on Wednesday to help given after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks as an example of a close relationship between two neighbors that do not always see eye to eye.

item.title: Ukraine Parliament Votes to Sack Government (Reuters)
item.description: Reuters - Ukraine's parliament on Wednesday voted to sack the government of Prime Minister Viktor Yanukovich, boosting opposition efforts to end a political crisis triggered by his contested election last month as president.

item.title: US, British Troops Raid Old Baathist Retreat (Reuters)
item.description: Reuters - Hundreds of U.S. and British troops raided homes of insurgent suspects at first light on Wednesday in an area that was once a favored country retreat of Saddam Hussein's Baath party elite.

item.title: Six Americans Confirmed Dead in Afghan Crash (Reuters)
item.description: Reuters - Search teams have discovered the wreckage of a U.S. aircraft that crashed in mountains in central Afghanistan at the weekend and confirmed that the six Americans aboard all died, the U.S. military said on Wednesday.

item.title: Ridge Leaving Cabinet (washingtonpost.com)
item.description: washingtonpost.com - Homeland Security Secretary Tom Ridge, the former governor and U.S. Army sergeant who became linked in the public mind with color-coded warnings of possible terrorist attacks, resigned yesterday after nearly two years overseeing the most ambitious U.S. government reorganization since the 1940s.

item.title: Bush, in Canada, Defends Foreign Policy (washingtonpost.com)
item.description: washingtonpost.com - OTTAWA, Nov. 30 -- President Bush, meeting here Tuesday with Prime Minister Paul Martin, declined to make trade concessions sought by Canada and told his international critics that the U.S. election was an endorsement of his administration's foreign policy.

item.title: Nuclear Agency Praises Iran (washingtonpost.com)
item.description: washingtonpost.com - The International Atomic Energy Agency praised Iran yesterday for suspending its uranium-enrichment work and removed an immediate threat of sanctions against the Islamic republic, which built its program in secret over 18 years.

item.title: Gutierrez Is Pick for Commerce Secretary (washingtonpost.com)
item.description: washingtonpost.com - President Bush began reshaping his economic team for a second term yesterday by nominating Carlos M. Gutierrez, the Cuban-born chief executive of the Kellogg cereal company, to replace Bush's friend Donald L. Evans as secretary of commerce.

item.title: Ukraine's President Calls for New Vote (washingtonpost.com)
item.description: washingtonpost.com - KIEV, Ukraine, Nov. 29 -- President Leonid Kuchma on Monday called for new elections to resolve a divisive crisis that has grown since government opponents and international monitors charged that a presidential runoff vote eight days ago was fraudulent.

item.title: Death penalty uneven across USA (USATODAY.com)
item.description: USATODAY.com - If Scott Peterson gets the death penalty, he becomes the highest-profile killer facing execution in the USA since Oklahoma City bomber Timothy McVeigh. But the Peterson case underscores unevenness around the country in applying the death penalty.

item.title: Deaths in combat ricochet here at home (USATODAY.com)
item.description: USATODAY.com - As if by ricochet, each American service man and woman killed in combat leaves behind a trail of secondary casualties: spouses, children, parents. Through Nov. 20, 45% of the 1,374 U.S. service personnel killed in Iraq and Afghanistan since September 2001 were married, the Defense Department says.

item.title: Ridge to quit terror agency (USATODAY.com)
item.description: USATODAY.com - Homeland Security Secretary Tom Ridge, who after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks presided over the biggest government reorganization in more than a half century, announced Tuesday that he will step down in February.

item.title: Laci's mother yells at Peterson (USATODAY.com)
item.description: USATODAY.com - An angry, sobbing Sharon Rocha screamed at her former son-in-law Scott Peterson on Tuesday in front of a stunned jury that will decide whether he lives or dies.

item.title: Census: 5.4 million mothers are choosing to stay at home (USATODAY.com)
item.description: USATODAY.com - The number of U.S. mothers who put work on hold and stayed home with children grew to 5.4 million in 2003, says the U.S. Census Bureau, which issued Tuesday its first analysis of "stay-at-home" parents.

item.title: Security Czar Ridge Resigns (Los Angeles Times)
item.description: Los Angeles Times - WASHINGTON — Declaring that the United States has become a much harder target for terrorists to strike, Tom Ridge announced his resignation Tuesday after nearly two years as the nation's first Homeland Security secretary.

item.title: PR Meets Psy-Ops in War on Terror (Los Angeles Times)
item.description: Los Angeles Times - WASHINGTON — On the evening of Oct. 14, a young Marine spokesman near Fallouja appeared on CNN and made a dramatic announcement.

item.title: Intelligence Bill Slipping Away, but Foe Won't Budge (Los Angeles Times)
item.description: Los Angeles Times - WASHINGTON — President Bush has personally lobbied him. Families of the Sept. 11 victims have publicly blamed him. But with time running out for Congress to enact a bill this year that would put a single official in charge of the nation's intelligence agencies, Rep. F. James Sensenbrenner Jr. (R-Wis.) is standing firm in opposition.

item.title: Justices Weigh Gender Equity Law (Los Angeles Times)
item.description: Los Angeles Times - WASHINGTON — The landmark gender equity law known as Title IX, which touched off a revolution in women's sports, came before the Supreme Court on Tuesday as the justices debated whether to protect coaches and teachers who complain that their schools or colleges fail to give girls equal treatment.

item.title: Mfume Steps Down as Head of the NAACP (Los Angeles Times)
item.description: Los Angeles Times - WASHINGTON — Kweisi Mfume, the former congressman from Baltimore who helped rescue the NAACP from debt and controversy nearly nine years ago, on Tuesday announced he was resigning as the president and chief executive of the venerable civil rights organization.
